importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, is central to the incident and marks the timeline of the tragic event involving Brett James.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time of the article's update reflects the most recent update on the investigation into the crash, indicating the current status of the NTSB report and public awareness of the event.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, during a flight to land on runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, with no mechanical issues found in the wreckage.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to change his radio frequency, leading to a loss of communication.
James never updated his radio frequency from the common traffic advisory frequency to the one assigned for runway 7, and continued to announce his position at 6,800 feet and a 360-degree turn.
The plane flew over the runway and executed a left turn before descending into a spiral and crashing.
Brett James was a prolific songwriter who collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, and co-wrote the hit 'Out Last Night'.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Radio frequency used by pilots to report position when no air traffic control is present

summaryOfNewsArticle: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for his work with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting to land on runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina. According to the National Transportation Safety Board’s preliminary report, the plane, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' after James failed to change his radio frequency from the common traffic advisory frequency, despite being instructed to do so. Air traffic control had approved a visual approach to runway 7, but communication was lost when James continued to announce his position at 6,800 feet and a 360-degree turn without tuning to the proper frequency. The NTSB found no mechanical issues with the aircraft, indicating that the crash was likely due to pilot error or miscommunication. The incident underscores the critical importance of maintaining proper radio communication in aviation operations.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, the NTSB said in a preliminary report
